origination.corpname: Interfaith Council for Peace and Justice (Ann Arbor, Mich.)

did.unittitle: Interfaith Council for Peace and Justice (Ann Arbor, Mich.) records 1966-2010
did.abstract: Records of the Interfaith Council For Peace and Justice, a Washtenaw County-based interdenominational organization encouraging participation in social justice education and activism. The collection is divided into twelve series, Chronological Files, Topical Files, Hunger Task Force, Clergy and Laity Concerned, Photographs and Audiovisual Materials, Steering Committee, Religious Coalition on Central America, Middle East Task Force, Racial and Economic Task Force, Disarmament Working Group, and Posters.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The records were received from the organization (donor no. 6539) in various accessions beginning in 1980.

accruals.p: Periodic additions to the records are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The record group is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has not been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Interfaith Council for Peace and Justice (Ann Arbor, Mich.) records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: In December 1965, members of various Ann Arbor religious congregations established an organization with the purpose of coordinating their opposition to the Vietnam War. Eventually named the Interfaith Council For Peace, the group's key organizer was Barbara Fuller, a representative of Memorial Christian Church in Ann Arbor. The Interfaith Council was chartered as a local chapter of the larger, national anti-war coalition, Clergy and Laity Concerned about Vietnam (name later changed to Clergy and Laity Concerned).

As opposition to the Vietnam War grew, both CALC and the IFC arranged a continuing series of activities and events designed to increase public dissatisfaction with the war and bring the conflict to a speedy conclusion. Barbara Fuller, in addition to her responsibilities in Ann Arbor, became an important figure in CALC. She served as the organization's regional coordinator for the Midwest and also was a member of CALC's national executive board.

The eventual conclusion of the war led to a re-evaluation of purpose among all anti-war groups. In Ann Arbor the Interfaith Council for Peace turned its attention to questions of social justice, particularly amnesty, human rights and world hunger. The IFC became the coordinating agency for an annual "hunger walk" in the community, an event designed to both dramatize the plight of the starving and to educate local residents about this problem. In 1988, the organization formally changed its name to the Interfaith Council for Peace and Justice (ICPJ).

Through the 1990s and 2000s, the ICPJ was highly involved in a wide variety of activities at the local, state, national and international levels. The group's yearly and monthly listings of events attest to their ongoing dedication to peace and justice and their high level of activism during this time. They continued their administrative role of the annual CROP Walk and also raised awareness regarding local hunger, homelessness, and welfare issues. They also held numerous protests and vigils to raise public awareness about the war in Bosnia, the "School of Assassins" at Fort Benning, support for a nuclear test ban, and opposition to U.S. bombings in Iraq. In addition, they hosted annually a day of "peaceful" events in remembrance of the bombing of Hiroshima, and in the late 1990s began training and coordinating a "Peace Team" to staff the local KKK rallies and anti-KKK protests in Ann Arbor.

scopecontent.p: The files of the Interfaith Council have been arranged into twelve series: Chronological Files, Topical Files, Hunger Task Force, Clergy and Laity Concerned, Photographs and Audiovisual Materials, Steering Committee, Religious Coalition on Central America, Middle East Task Force, Racial and Economic Task Force, Disarmament Working Group, and Posters.

scopecontent.p: The Chronological Files series (7.4 linear feet) is comprised primarily of meeting minutes, correspondence, announcements of upcoming events, and newspaper clippings which document the history of the organization, its activities, and socio-political concerns, from 1966-2010. Also included in this series is the organization's Constitution and By-Laws.

did.unittitle: University of Michigan Classified Research and Vietnam

scopecontent.p: The Topical Files series (8 linear feet) was originally created as a reference file for various anti-war activities and is arranged alphabetically by subject. Because many of the activities were sponsored by either CALC or ICPJ, this series contains much overlapping CALC and ICPJ material. Most of the material from the 1990s and 2000s relates to the ICPJ's Middle East Task Force and Hiroshima Day observances.

did.unittitle: Ad Hoc Coalition for a New Foreign Policy 1975-1976
St. Francis of Assisi Catholic Church 1996-2003
Petition to Free Two Draft Resisters from Prison 1974
Bethlehem United Church of Christ Grant 2003-2005
Inside Out (publication of Prisoners' Progress Association), 1975
Michigan Council to Repeal the Draft 1968-1971
National Coalition Against War, Racism and Repression 1970-1971
Peoples Coalition For Peace and Justice 1971-1974
Vietnam and America, Conference in Ann Arbor 1971
Michigan Peace and Justice Directory (of similar organizations) Undated

scopecontent.p: The Hunger Task Force series (6 linear feet) also overlaps with the Chronology of the ICPJ and is divided into two subseries, Chronological Files and CROP Walk Topical Files. The Chronological Files subseries documents the Hunger Task Force subcommittee of the ICPJ and the hunger-related issues addressed and events conducted by the organization from 1974-2008. The CROP Walk Topical Files, dating from the mid-1990s, document the planning and execution of the Washtenaw County CROP Walk.

The Clergy and Laity Concerned series (2.7 linear feet), documents the activities and correspondence, primarily of the organization's National Office, from 1966 to 1990. Also included are events announcements, correspondence, and newsletters from CALC Affiliate offices.

The Photographs and Audiovisual Materials series (2 linear feet) includes Vietnam-era photographs, negatives, and slides of ICPJ members and events, including a Walk for Hunger and Crater Dig and a scrapbook containing photographs and fliers relating to the 2002-2003 CROP walks. Additionally there are audiotapes of a series of meeting between ICPJ members and US Representative Carl Pursell, as well as audio and video recordings of other ICPJ sponsored events and lectures.

did.unittitle: 1960s activities: include photographs and slides of demonstrations organized in opposition to America's involvement in Vietnam and to the problem of poverty and hunger in the United States; include photos of "crater digs," a March against hunger, and other protest gatherings
Globalization, David Bonior and David Korton 2005

"The Fading Family Farm" undated. A presentation dealing with the loss of farmland and family farmers in Washtenaw County. 15 minutes. Produced by Ken Ludwig, former country agent with Washtenaw County Extension Service slide show by Diane Wahner, a former graduate student in the UM Department of Natural Resources.

scopecontent.p: The Steering Committee series (1 linear foot) is comprised of minutes, agendas, correspondence, financial, etc. documenting the decisions made during its monthly meetings. The committee nominated its members from local congregations, and met regularly to plan the activities and goals of the ICPJ.

did.unittitle: Religious Coalition on Central America/Latin American Taskforce

scopecontent.p: The Religious Coalition on Central America (1 linear foot) series documents the working body of the ICPJ which focused on issues relating to Central American countries. The series is organized by topic as well as chronologically. Public events and encouraging dialogue within the religious community were a large part of their efforts. The RCLA was later renamed the Latin American Task Force.

did.unittitle: Repopulation of Salvadoran Countryside by Returning Refugees
The Revolution Will not be televised (event) 2004

scopecontent.p: The Middle East Task Force (1.5 linear feet) documents the working body of the ICPJ which focused on issues relating to Middle Eastern countries. The series is organized by topic as well as chronologically. Public events and encouraging dialogue within the religious community were a large part of their effort.

did.unittitle: Campaign to End the Israeli Occupation
American Friends Service Committee Board of Directors

scopecontent.p: The Racial and Economic Task Force (1.5 linear feet) series documents the working body of the ICPJ which focused on promoting racial and economic justice. The series is organized by topic as well as chronologically. Public events and encouraging dialogue within the religious community were a large part of their efforts.

did.unittitle: May 9th Rally for CommUNITY and Justice 1998

scopecontent.p: The Disarmament Working Group (1.5 linear feet) documents the working body of the ICPJ which focused on non-violent resolutions of personal, community, and international conflict. The series is organized by topic and as well as chronologically. Public events and encouraging dialogue within the religious community were a large part of their efforts.

did.unittitle: National Council of the Churches of Christ -- USSR Travel Seminar
Southeastern Michigan Peace and Justice Coalition
World Peace Tax Fund -- War Tax Resistance

scopecontent.p: The Posters series documents the events and issues of most concern to the organization. When received this series consisted of poster board displays made up of original photographs and documents. Mainly because of their size, most of these poster board displays were photographed. Their contents were then removed from the poster boards. The folders in this series consist of a scanned photograph of each display and the individual items removed from each poster board.

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous photographs and flyers taken from over-sized poster board displays

odd.p: (1st folder includes CD-ROM of the posters)

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Newsletters of the ICPJ have been removed from this record group and cataloged and located separately.
